natural problem: Six horses eat 12 bales of hay in 12 hours. At the same rate, how many hours will 36 bales of hay last 12 horses?
natural solution: From the original rate, we note that 12 horses will eat 12 bales of hay in 6 hours. (Double the number of horses, half the time)  Therefore, 12 horses will eat 36 bales of hay in $\boxed{18\text{ hours}}$.
(Triple the amount of hay, triple the time)

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes horses bales hours :: real
assumes h0 : "horses = 6"
and h1 : "bales = 12"
and h2 : "hours = 12"
and h3 : "horses * hours = bales"
shows  "(36 * hours) / 12 = 18"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six horses eat 12 bales of hay in 12 hours. At the same rate, how many hours will 36 bales of hay last 12 horses? The final Answer is 18\text{ hours}
 ### Proof
 From the original rate, we note that 12 horses will eat 12 bales of hay in 6 hours. (Double the number of horses, half the time)  Therefore, 12 horses will eat 36 bales of hay in $\boxed{18\text{ hours}}$.
 (Triple the amount of hay, triple the time)
 *)

theorem
fixes horses bales hours :: real
assumes h0 : "horses = 6"
and h1 : "bales = 12"
and h2 : "hours = 12"
and h3 : "horses * hours = bales"
shows  "(36 * hours) / 12 = 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: If 6 horses can eat 12 bales of hay in 12 hours, how many bales of hay would 36 horses eat in 12 hours? The final answer is 18.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes horses bales hours :: real
assumes h0 : "6 * horses * hours = 12 * bales"
shows  "36 * bales / 12 * horses = 18 * hours"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 ### Proof

 (Triple the amount of hay, triple the time)
 *)

theorem
fixes horses bales hours :: real
assumes h0 : "6 * horses * hours = 12 * bales"
shows  "36 * bales / 12 * horses = 18 * hours"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: If 6 horses can eat 12 bales of hay in a certain number of hours, how many hours will it take for the same number of horses to eat 36 bales of hay? The final answer is 18 hours.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes horses bales hours :: real
assumes h0 : "6 * horses * 12 * hours = 12 * bales"
shows  "12 * horses * x * hours = 36 * bales \<Longrightarrow> x = 18"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six horses eat 12 bales of hay in 12 hours. At the same rate, how many hours will 36 bales of hay last 12 horses? The final Answer is 18\text{ hours}
 ### Proof

 (Triple the amount of hay, triple the time)
 *)

fixes horses bales hours :: real
assumes h0 : "6 * horses * 12 * hours = 12 * bales"
shows  "12 * horses * x * hours = 36 * bales \<Longrightarrow> x = 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: If 6 horses can eat 12 bales of hay in a certain number of hours, how many horses would need to eat 36 bales of hay in the same amount of time, if each horse eats 18 times as much hay per hour?
